      • getHttpCode

        int getHttpCode()
                throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Returns last request's Http Status Code. If no request have been made, or if an exception is thrown (ex : the request hast not even been launched), the function will send an IllegalStateException
        Returns:
        last Status Code
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if no request has been made, or last request did not complete

      • POST

        java.lang.String POST(java.lang.String relativeFileWithNoParam,
                    Representation representation)
                      throws HttpException

        Execute a POST request toward a specified Resource, with evenutal parameters.

        If ApplicationUri is set to http://localhost:8080/mywebapp/ and relativeFileWithNoParam is set to user/register.jsp, then the request is sent to http://localhost:8080/mywebapp/user/register.jsp

        Params are set by a CoupleList ; null is accepted for no param

        It's also possible to set the "pure entity" of the request by using setEntityToNextRequest() before using this function. See the turorial for detailed exemple

        Parameters:
        relativeFileWithNoParam -
        representation - Classic parameters added to the request.
        Returns:
        The content of the Response
        Throws:
        HttpException - : When we can't send the request (malformed Uri) or if there is no server response (no connection, no server, etc.)
        RestException - : When the server sends back an error described by a status code (401, 500, etc.)

      • GET

        java.lang.String GET(java.lang.String relativeFileWithNoParam,
                   CoupleList<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> parameters)
                     throws HttpException

        Execute a POST request toward a specified Resource, with evenutal parameters.

        If ApplicationUri is set to http://localhost:8080/mywebapp/ and relativeFileWithNoParam is set to user/register.jsp, then the request is sent to http://localhost:8080/mywebapp/user/register.jsp

        Params are set by a CoupleList ; null is accepted for no param. Here is an easy way to set params :

        URL params ?firstname=James&city=London is set by CoupleList.builder("firstname", "James","city","London")

        It's also possible to set the "pure entity", but it"s not recommanded for a GET request.

        Parameters:
        relativeFileWithNoParam -
        parameters - Classic parameters added to the request.
        Returns:
        The content of the Response
        Throws:
        HttpException - : When we can't send the request (malformed Uri) or if there is no server response (no connection, no server, etc.)
        RestException - : When the server sends back an error described by a status code (401, 500, etc.)

      • PUT

        java.lang.String PUT(java.lang.String relativeFileWithNoParam,
                   Representation representation)
                     throws HttpException
        Execute a PUT request. The _method param is NOT used neither needed.
        Parameters:
        relativeFileWithNoParam -
        representation -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        HttpException - : When we can't send the request (malformed Uri) or if there is no server response (no connection, no server, etc.)
        RestException - : When the server sends back an error described by a status code (401, 500, etc.)

      • get

        void get(java.lang.String relativePath,
       CoupleList<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> parameters,
       Callback callback)
         throws HttpException

        Execute a GET Http request. The relative apth compares to the AbsolutePath

        For exemple, if ApplicationUri has been set to http://exemple.com/mycontext/, a relative url of students/johndoe will set a GET request to the http://exemple.com/mycontext/johndoe resource.

        The request handles parameters that will be added to the url request. You might use CoupleList.build(param1, value1, param2, value2) to set these parameters.

        AsyncCallback refers to GWT

        Parameters:
        relativePath - compare to ApplicationUri path
        parameters -
        callback -
        Throws:
        HttpException
        RestException
